channel.title: Is this Math?
channel.description: Recent content on Is this Math?

item.title: Walking through the delta method
item.description: Imagine weâ€™ve constructed an estimator \(T_n\) for some parameter \(\theta\) but what we really want to know about is \(\phi(\theta)\), some transformation of the parameter. Can we use our knowledge of the behavior of \(T_n\) to learn about \(\phi(T_n)\)? By the continuous-mapping theorem if \(\phi\) is continuous then: if \(T_n \to \theta\) then \(\phi(T_n) \to \phi(\theta)\) By the delta method we have if \(\sqrt{n}(T_n - \theta) \rightsquigarrow T\) as \(n \to \infty\) then \(\sqrt{n}(\phi(T_n) - \phi(\theta)) \rightsquigarrow \phi'_\theta(T)\) where \(\phi'_\theta(T) = \phi'(\theta)*T\).

item.title: O notation depends on what limit you're taking
item.description: Something that confused me about \(O\) notation was that it appeared to take different meaning between algorithms and calculus. This was resolved by seeing that the notation provides a convenient way of describing the limit of a function \(f(x)\) as \(x\) approaches a specific limit. This point about the \(O\)-ness of a function being contingent on what limit you were taking was the crux of my confusion. This limit is typically different between a standard algorithms and calculus course.

item.title: Calculating the determinent of an equicovariance matrix
item.description: The goal is to find the determinant by re-writing \(\Sigma\) as a upper triangular matrix. Then [[Determinant of triangular matrix is the product of the diagonal]] We add a new row and new column. Recall that the determinant can be defined recursively. Since the new matrix has a \(1\) in the \(\Sigma_{11}\) position, then the determinant remains the same. We aim to eliminate the original off diagonals. We need to remove the lower diagonal for obvious reasons.

item.title: About
item.description: This is a “hello world” example website for the blogdown package. The theme was forked from @jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme and modified by Yihui Xie.
